reasoning: The critique targets the fixed α=0.5 assumption used to generate the post’s concrete “max speed” ceilings and some downstream intuitions (e.g., when bottlenecks bite). That assumption is not the only pillar of the overall anti-bottleneck case (much hinges on ρ and on qualitative arguments about experimentation), but it is materially involved in the numeric claims and the comparison to economic estimates, so centrality is moderate. The critique is fairly strong: for ρ<0, the ceiling as L→∞ is Y_max=(αK^ρ)^{1/ρ}=α^{1/ρ}K, which is extremely sensitive to α when ρ is mildly negative (e.g., with ρ=-0.2, moving α from 0.5 to 0.8 drops the ceiling from 32× to ~3×). This undercuts the rhetorical force of the plotted ceilings and could affect the “bottlenecks bite late” takeaway if α is high or changes over time. Correctness is high: α-sensitivity and the direction of the effect are right, though α is not literally a task-fraction and the proposed interpretation (“compute-driven ⇒ α≈1”) is only an imperfect mapping. The critique is clear, tightly focused, and has little filler.
title: The fixed α=0.5 assumption hides critical sensitivity in speed ceilings
